title: Greetings & Respect
description: Learn the greetings that connect you to your family and show respect to elders.

lessons.title: Basic Greetings
lessons.situation_description: You arrive at your grandparents' compound in Fuuta Jallon. The whole family is gathered in the courtyard. How do you greet everyone properly?

phrases.english: Thank you / Peace be upon you
phrases.cultural_note: "A jaraama" is more than "thank you" — it expresses gratitude for someone's presence and acknowledges their dignity.
This greeting affirms that peace exists between you. It's both a greeting and a blessing.
A caring inquiry about someone's wellbeing. The expected response is "Jam tan" (Only peace).
The standard reassuring reply. Even when things are hard, this response honors the bond between speakers.

exercises.instruction: Match each Pular phrase to its English meaning

tindol.english: A single heart does not speak — meaning: we need each other to communicate and live well.

lessons.title: Greeting Elders with Respect
lessons.situation_description: Your grandmother comes to visit and you want to show her the deepest respect in Pular tradition. How do you greet an elder properly?

phrases.cultural_note: "On" is the respectful form of "you." Always use this with elders, teachers, and anyone deserving special respect.

phrases.english: Did you spend the night in peace?
phrases.cultural_note: A morning greeting asking about the night. Showing concern for an elder's rest is a sign of deep respect.

phrases.english: Did you spend the day in peace?
phrases.cultural_note: An evening greeting. Pular greetings change with the time of day, showing attentiveness to others' daily experience.
"Seydi" means elder or respected person. Addressing someone as "seydi am" (my elder) shows the highest form of respect.

exercises.instruction: Match each respectful greeting to its meaning

tindol.english: A great mother makes a great household — meaning: respect for elders is the foundation of family life.
